segments.phrase_text: Hi, Hemal. How are you?
I'm doing good, Nicola. Thank you so much for inviting me for beer.
Yeah, I think we should start with a toast, right?
Yeah. Cheers.
Cheers.
Cheers.
Ah, nice beer.
Nice one.
So...
So, yeah, how, how do we met? We met yesterday for the first time in real life.
Yes.
And now we are here talking-
Yes.
... and spending some time together.
Yes.
That's so cool.
Thank you so much, uh, for this, uh, invitation for this interview.
Mm-hmm.
Yesterday, we had an amazing, uh, n8n starter session in Barcelona. It's an official tour from
n8n across seven countries, Europe and US. Um,
it was great to meet you.
Yeah. Thank you. And there were so many people. The vibes were, were so great.
Yes.
And, and I was actually... We were talking about this before, right? I was inspired by hearing your
story. And apart from all the cool stuff that you do with n8n, automations, AI, th- which is
amazing, but what I really like and, um,
relate to you was, like, your motivation behind all of this, like, why you are doing this.
Sure.
Why you are doing this?
Thank you. Thank you so much. Yeah, uh, to be honest, the reason I'm, uh, I'm
doing all this AI education, especially with the
monthly, um,
free workshops and all the n8n ambassador program, uh, is because, uh, I started
learning coding when I was, like, 16 year old or 15 years old, um, in a developing country, um,
or even underdeveloped as a refugee in Pakistan. Um,
and the reason that I was exposed to this, uh, computer programming education early on in my life, despite having
very mediocre lifestyle or, or maybe even a poor lifestyle I would say,
uh, that it, uh, early exposure to, to AI... not AI, but, like, coding,
brought me today here where I am. Otherwise, I might have ended up in a totally different, uh, circumstance in
my life, financially speaking, educationally, and also lifestyle-wise. And I want to
pay back to the community and, and, and teach a lot of, uh, 16 years old kids around the world,
whether this be in India, Pakistan, Afghanistan, Bangladesh, uh, South America, wh- wherever it is. Like, uh, there are a
lot of developing countries with internet connections that they can play a YouTube video. And if get, they get, uh,
one of my YouTube videos, uh, and they, they learn how to build, uh, something, I,
I would be really, really happy. And it's just the start of the journey. I'm-
Yeah, just the beginning.
... way far away from that
first million
16 year old kids who will, uh, who will learn from my content.
Mm-hmm.
Yeah.
I see. I s-... That's, like, really the best mission. And
I remember yesterday you were saying that you're already hearing back stories from, from kids in, in India or, or
somewhere else that-
Yeah.
... writes you, right?
Yeah.
Saying, "I, I watched your video, and it was so helpful, so clear, like this, uh, eight hours long
video."
Yeah.
"And I can just followed it, put in, uh, in, in the work, and help someone in, in my community,
my neighborhood, the, the shop nearby, the, the, um, the doctor, and-"
Yes.
"... help them right away thanks to code and AI."
Yes, uh, that-
That's super cool.
... uh, that's amazing. Like, each time I get these
either shout-outs on LinkedIn that people
learned something, did something, or, or they send me a DM, they say like, "Thank you so much for this
tutorial you're putting in." It's, it's, um, kind of the fuel I need in order to produce more and more
and more. Uh, and, and this kid from India sent me a message that he started building this little voice
AI agent. And, uh, many, many more like those examples come.
Mm-hmm.
And it's, as I said, it's just the start. I, I started my journey literally a few months ago, and
it's gonna get, uh, I think, bigger and bigger. I'm, uh-
It's moving pretty fast.
I'm so passionate about this.
Yeah.
Yeah.
And, and then I, I think you have just, uh, started a company in the last month-
Yeah.
... or last few months.
Yeah.
Right? What, what's your, um, uh, goal with that? Or what do you... what are you cooking now?
So, with this new company, Avinai, um, Chris and I are, uh,
building AI agents, or kind of
in a metaphorical way, we are reimagining work. Uh, we believe that in the near
future, the work as we know it will change. And we at Avinai are at the fore- at the forefront
of reimagining how work is done. Uh, and I, I believe with this agentic workflows, with AI
agents, and with AI automation, we can definitely rethink about how work should be done, because a lot of work
is repetitive. And especially in enterprise level, there, there are a lot of automation, uh, opportunities that
even low-hanging fruits could be like automating, copy-pasting from one system to another system that ca-... that could be done,
uh, anyways by literally gluing two APIs together. But now, if you find, like, an horizontal use case where
across multiple systems...... an AI agent can have an
a- access to all those tools
and
perform those actions across those tools. Uh, it will create an enormous, um, value for
that particular organization. Uh, and I think it's just the start. It's gonna get bigger.
So, you, you think, uh, that it's like rethinking
the, the way of working with AI? How do you
help the company, uh, a client, a, a company, uh, go about it, right?
So, yeah. The, the, the reason that we
want to kind of like bring this visibility of reimagining or rethinking how work is done is
because until now, we have been using computers in a way to
enable us to do our job better. And now, computers can do the job. So therefore, it's
time that we have to rethink or reimagine how work is done.
It's not that we're gonna... for example, Excel. Excel was very good to do calculations, but enabled us to do
better calculation. Now, let's take an example of an AI agent that is doing invoices.
It's gonna do the reconciliation for you. It's gonna do the booking for you. It's gonna do the travel expenses,
the r- uh, the payroll and everything else for you. So, you have to, at the principal level, rethink
and reimagine how work should be done.
Yeah.
And that's where we, we play, uh, uh, an extremely, um, crucial role because we not only bring
in the, um,
the empowering, uh,
capabilities, but also from the day one, we, we bring in the discovery phase to it, uh, with workshops
initially, and then enablement, uh, sessions and development sessions and maintenance and, and so on and so forth.
Yeah.
So, kind of like a 360-degree service company.
'Cause I, I, I hear more and more people saying this, that with, with AI, it's a lot about people
right now.
Like,
the tool or the
brain of AI is already extremely good to do most of the work.
Mm-hmm.
But the issue is how people use it, or
the famous AI adoption that is not a- as easy, especially the, the bigger the company. Uh, so there
is
some help there needed, right?
Uh, yeah. The AI adoption right now, um, especially the, the, the blockers in SMEs and-
Mm-hmm.
... big companies, uh, can be understandable because it's not so high and, and the reason is because
usually these AI, um, models could hallucinate. So, we have guardrails, but they are so
young. Like, every single project that you can pick that can, um, enable, uh, an
AI agent to reduce the hallucinations and put the right guardrails, those projects by themselves are like three, four, five,
six months old. Now,
the enterprise is not adopting it
yet, uh, because of the immaturity of those projects. But they're developing so fast that
I believe in six months,
they will be enterprise-ready.
Mm-hmm.
But the... on the other side of the spectrum,
there are certain things that can be used today in, uh, enterprise. Uh, for example, let's take an,
uh, a simple workflow in n8n. Um, by the way, Avanade is an n8n expert company.
We do n8n workshops and n8n, uh,
implementation for enterprises.
So, let's take an n8n workflow. You, you do n8n workflows for companies.
You already know how easy it is or how secure it is to, to put an n8n workflow that
does, let's say, ticket cal- classification. Enterprises get these support tickets in thousands.
Mm-hmm.
And usually, there's a workflow or a process that a human being
has access to an inbox. Let's say help at Allianz or support at Allianz.de, for
example. And, and they decide, okay, this label goes to it, this label goes to it, this one goes to
that department, this one goes to that department. So, there's a lot of labeling and, and, and routing and things
that today's AI can do it with a very high degree of certainty.
Yeah.
Can be done with today's AI. And also, I, I teach a lot about EU AI Act in my, uh,
workshops.
Mm-hmm.
Happy to discuss about that more. I don't want to go on a monologue.
Sorry, uh, like this kind of thing.
Yeah, no, no worries. Go on.
But, but, like, these, uh, compliance s- or legal side effect can also be done with n8n and, and with
the current AI tech stack we have. So, from one side, high-risk, um,
applications should not be done with AI yet. But in the next six months to one year, it's possible. Uh,
on the other side, uh, low-risk, um, applications, uh, can be done today with AI. And I think, uh, the
enterprise is just catching up and it's the best time to provide these services.
Yeah. I think that
there is,
there are, as y- as you said, already ways to, to figure out the legal and the, the other kind
of, of things, right? The, the formalities. But if a company wants to do it and puts in the right
effort, it's...... working, right?
Yeah.
You can really do that.
Yes.
And you have, you have said a few things about enterprise and big companies. How do you see, uh, right
now the- the use cases or the application for, uh, small companies, medium companies that have
no idea of how to use it? They want to do something with it, but they don't know where to
start. Like, they are overwhelmed.
Um,
eh, s- especially small businesses, like for example, this, uh, restaurant, beautiful restaurant, a lot of
customers. If they start... The- the owner of this restaurant starts thinking about implementing an AI agent in
their workflow, they are the right people to identify which process is so repeated. Don't-
Yeah.
Uh, kind of like if I was building AI agents for small restaurants, uh, not chains, small restaurants, I would
go and talk to them, and I would not tell them that A- AI agents can do this and that.
I wouldn't show them N8N workflows. I wouldn't try to sell all the bells and whistles of AI agents. I
would go and talk to them, and I would say, "Can you show me which workflow do you do? Like,
what is the most repetitive workflow that you do?" And most probably, you will find a workflow that is doable
with the current AI agent's workflow automation, uh, I mean, AI, uh, automation.
And then you pick one niche that is so repetitive, like every day they do the same thing again and
again. For example, they take these slips, they put it in this, like, big, uh,
pin. It's a pile of slips, and then they kind of like reconcile it somewhere, or key punch it, or
scan it, or do something with it.
Mm-hmm.
That's doable. Like, in this N8N starter, uh, workshop, one of the workflows is receipt scanning.
Perhaps they need this, uh, receipt scanning. And you- you- you know how to do it. It's so simple.
Yeah, it's simple.
Uh, and then if you can automate that one workflow for them, that they scan a receipt with Google Drive,
it goes and sits there on a, as a PDF, and it does an entry on Google Sheets. And it
is perhaps also connected with their POS, their point of sales.
Uh, and- and then maybe it does a s- uh, a push notification with some summaries every hour to the
owner
from all the branches that he has on Slack.
Yeah.
This kind of a workflow is already doable. And then you, you do it perfectly for one restaurant, and then
you start going around in Barcelona city, and then you keep selling it to the next restaurants. I think the
ROI for this, for let- even if you sell it for a thousand euros,
and it takes you one hour to install it. Uh, let's say another
two hours in total accumulated across all your sales pipelines
per client. So in three hours, you're making a thousand euros. It's an extremely luc- lucrative business. Um,
now imagine if you can
sell more of this by hiring people. On the other side, it's also lucrative for the business because something that
they used to do with hand, with human brain, now can be done with AI. So the ROI for the
restaurant is positive already. A thousand euro is nothing for a restaurant to put a kind of tech stack that's
frontier and it's agentic, it's-
it's top-notch, uh, quality. And also you can provide support with that 1,000 euros. Maybe you- you put another package
on the top, 300 euros per year for- for unlimited support.
Yeah.
You can imagine like a workflow like that, how much support it needs. But 300 euro is like 30 euros
subscription per month.
Mm-hmm.
So you build yourself a service business that pays upfront some money, and then on a- on a- on a
monthly basis, a recurring revenue. And also, when you get into a restaurant, then it's not one workflow. Next time
they need another workflow, another two, three thousand euro-
Yeah.
... another two, three thousand euros.
Okay.
So that way you build yourself a- a lucrative ag- AI automation agency business.
Okay. Okay. And
okay, so you- you have touched
many points that
are like now becoming buzzwords and because of the hype around AI agents, blah, blah, blah, all these things
that
we always talk about it. But most people outside
our tech bubble don't know yet what does it mean. So if I am, um, a small business or a
creative agency, uh, and I have no idea about AI, um,
can you explain how to think about
the difference maybe between AI agents, workflows, what is an AI agent in
three words, and how a business can say, "Okay, here
we need this kind of thing. Here it's better. This, this other stuff." You know what I mean?
So...
In simple-
In- in simple words, maybe not three words, a little bit more.
Uh, like 30 words, let's say.
Okay, 30.
Um,
if I want to explain
what is an AI agent to my mother, that's how I will explain it.
Yeah.
An AI agent
is a software, um, that mimics the way
a human
performs tasks on a computer. That basically can work like the way a human can work on a
computer. There are different types of AI agents, the same way as there are different types of people using computers.
For example, there's a person
using Google Sheets doing accounting.
Uh, or there's a person using Google Docs.... writing, uh, documentation about something.
And that's how the AI agents can be different. And the, the most important part about AI agent is it
has like, why do we call it agent?
Yeah.
Because it has
agency. It can do things on its own. Um, the same way like James Bond, for example, if we take
James Bond as a connotation, um,
James Bond is an agent.
Okay.
He's a 007 A- agent, uh, of, um... Which country is it? US or, or British?
UK.
UK, British.
So, he goes and performs tasks in other co- uh, in other countries or in the same country, and then
he has tools, uh, that he
has, like a car that can drive and that can swim, that can fire, that can change the number plates.
That tool is important. So an AI agent
can have like a Google Sheet as a tool that can perform accounting tasks or can have a Gmail access
that can perform, um, an email com- composing an email. Uh, and, and then
James Bond has a very sharp memory. He can remember things. Uh, he can memorize things because he wants to
make sure that he can find the right criminal at the right time and then take it to the law.
And so is the case with an AI agent. An AI agent needs to kind of like remember things. For
example, if I ha- I have built an AI agent that
takes care of my email inbox
and I say that compose an email or send an email to John Doe and mention that I am gonna
be 20 minutes late, it should remember that who is John Doe
and where can I find his, his email address, and that's the memory part of an AI agent. So an

over time. Sorry, that was not three words or 30 words.
I, I, I've never heard that, but I, I love the James Bond comparison. Now, I, I'm
building in my head a world around an AI agent like James Bond.
Yeah.
Yeah, it makes sense because like James Bonds receives from his boss, uh, like a goal-
Yeah.
... like
find this criminal and kill him, let's say.
Right? And it's something like that, right?
I hope he doesn't kill him and bring him to prison, but...
Okay. Okay. Right. Let's say bring him to prison.
So you, you give the AI agent as well a goal, right?
Yes.
You can give it a goal and you give it tools, maybe an Excel, Google Sheet is not as cool
as James Bond car, but-
Yeah.
... does the job. So he can then pick the right tools
in the order that the brain of the AI agent-
Yeah.
... at the side, right? To reach a certain goal basically.
Yes.
Make sense?

there must be a dozen more metaphors that we can come up with.
Yeah.
ChatGPT should help.

steps?

workflow,
when to decide to put an AI agent or, or, or-
Yeah.
... when to put, uh, AI capabilities in it,
eh, it will kind of like
become visible as soon as you start building it. If it's something to do with very
unclear inputs,
then most probably you need an AI agent node in n8n.
Mm-hmm.
For example, coming back to this receipt for this restaurant. Receipts can be scanned
and receipts can be of different types of data input. It already is indicating that it needs AI integration

And AI is very good in recognizing patterns and extracting text from

your workflow. But on the other side, if you want to have a workflow that is just like running

In that case, you don't need AI because it's just like a pipeline that goes like from one, data flows
from one side, goes to the other side.
Mm-hmm.
So in that case, you don't need, uh, any AI integration.
Okay.
I think it's just the workflow when you start building it, it will identify itself that, oh, okay, here I,
I need AI. And then it's agentic and it's an AI automation. Uh, and, and gradually, it will

ingredients that makes an AI agent, an AI agent.
Mm-hmm. Okay. Yeah. So when the things are, yeah, not clear and usually need a human to decide what

to, to use an AI agent, right?
Yes.
Yes. Okay.
Wonderful.
Wonderful. I think we can

And finish our beer. Thanks. Thanks to you.
